Articles.Content:
Gentlemen and ladies, 

I am new to the KSP world and love it. The challenge and possibilities are awesome. On to the question. I built a Kerbal X rocket as a lifter to the moon. 6 boosters with 2 X FLT 800s each and a LV-T30 as their engine. Main stage is the orange rocko max with a 16 rocko max tank utilizing the Mainsail. It is lifting my somewhat custom made Munar lander. All stages are correctly placed and to top it off, 1 hour before this launch I used the same exact setup to launch a previous Munar lander. The intent was to send two landers to the Mun, one would get science in high orbit the other in low orbit and some science from the surface provided I hadnt wasted my Delta V. 

Now to the interesting part, Boosters get jettisoned just fine, no change from the previous launch, I get into orbit and jettison the ferrings. Next stage seperates  the main from the Munar and ignites the maneuver rocket attached too the Munar Lander. Here is where it got wierd, the main view stayed on the jettisoned main stage and my Munar Landar took off in a shot like a missile shot from a jet as I watched it leave,  I could not regain control by hitting the square bracket keys or right clicking or anything. Was too tired to fiddle with it last night so I just went to bed. Has this happened to anyone else? Hopefully this is just a weird glitch or maybe I hit a control button unaware that i had done so.

Is it possible your root part is on the lifter not the payload?  Might be worth right clicking on the command module and selecting "Control from here" before you launch it next time to see if that solves it.  Square bracket only works within a given range so it's possible you out of range by the time you hit the key.

Or it might just be a weird random bug

Edited January 23, 2016 by RizzoTheRat
Never thought of that! Great idea, thank you.

okay, that wasnt it. I got in the same predicament but was fast enough to hit the bracket key to regain control of it this time. So to keep this from happening again, the root part needs to be on my final stage correct?

39 minutes ago, TheOldDad said:

okay, that wasnt it. I got in the same predicament but was fast enough to hit the bracket key to regain control of it this time. So to keep this from happening again, the root part needs to be on my final stage correct?

Correct, the camera will follow the root part.

You can also break down your staging into two parts, or throttle down before you stage, that way your lander doesn't go shooting off into the wild blue yonder.
Go into the last gadget in the editor (or click 4) and click right under your command pod, and then on the command pod.  It should switch the root to the correct one.

Couldn't you just right click the last command pod/module and select "control from here" before staging? (Honestly asking here, never encountered this situation myself)

Also, even if the brackets fail due to the vessel getting to far away you could'ave gone to the map view and selected it, then switched to it.

But yeah, as others have said...making it the root part should solve your problems the easiest way. Best of luck!
I tried that pocket, it didnt work. I havnt had a problem ever since i rebuilt the whole ship.
